Now that the Washington Redskins have retired their name and logo, some wonder when Mass. high schools will do the sameMany town leaders acknowledge Native American mascots have been a source of controversy for decades. But even during this watershed moment of racial reckoning, few have made plans to change or even discuss their school mascots, despite mounting criticism from students and alumni.

In time of racial reckoning, Founding Fathers increasingly viewed through modern lensThe Founding Fathers are facing renewed scrutiny. “The Revolution had very little regard for the lives of Africans and Native Americans,” says playwright Miranda ADEkoje. “White supremacy is just weaved into the fabric of this country. Not recognizing the humanity of everyone, especially those whose skins were not white, is so ingrained.”

Perspective | MagazineYoung people believe activism can help. But voting? That’s a different storyIt’s absurd to think we aren’t voting in huge numbers because we’re unengaged. It's because the electoral system needs to earn our trust.

Walpole’s beloved ‘Dog Rock’ rolls its way into mask controversyFor nearly two decades, Walpole resident Joey Dugdale has been the self-appointed caretaker of the town’s “Dog Rock,” a boulder painted to look like a black-and-white puppy’s face. But when he recently painted a mask onto the landmark’s snout to honor health care workers, he touched off a dogfight in the Norfolk County community that’s been playing out both online and in stone.

Not recognizing the humanity of everyone, especially those whose skins were not white, is so ingrained.”

All migrant children must be released from US detention by Friday because of coronavirus. Some parents fear that could mean separationOne Haitian couple and dozens of others face a cruel choice: abandon their asylum claims and face imminent deportation with their children to countries where their lives are in danger or allow their children to be released to a sponsor or relative here and risk separation if the parents are later deported.

BPDA could give green light Thursday to stalled Winthrop Center skyscraperThe Boston Planning & Development Agency board is set to vote Thursday on changes to the partially built Winthrop Center tower on Federal Street, revisions that would make it slightly smaller and allow planned condominiums to instead be rental apartments. The developer says the changes are essential to resuming work on the project.

Walpole’s beloved ‘Dog Rock’ rolls its way into mask controversyFor nearly two decades, Walpole resident Joey Dugdale has been the self-appointed caretaker of the town’s “Dog Rock,” a boulder painted to look like a black-and-white puppy’s face. But when he recently painted a mask onto the landmark’s snout to honor health care workers, he touched off a dogfight in the Norfolk County community that’s been playing out both online and in stone.

Now that the Washington Redskins have retired their name and logo, some wonder when Mass. high schools will do the sameMany town leaders acknowledge Native American mascots have been a source of controversy for decades. But even during this watershed moment of racial reckoning, few have made plans to change or even discuss their school mascots, despite mounting criticism from students and alumni.

Not recognizing the humanity of everyone, especially those whose skins were not white, is so ingrained.”

BPDA could give green light Thursday to stalled Winthrop Center skyscraperThe Boston Planning & Development Agency board is set to vote Thursday on changes to the partially built Winthrop Center tower on Federal Street, revisions that would make it slightly smaller and allow planned condominiums to instead be rental apartments. The developer says the changes are essential to resuming work on the project.

Now that the Washington Redskins have retired their name and logo, some wonder when Mass. high schools will do the sameMany town leaders acknowledge Native American mascots have been a source of controversy for decades. But even during this watershed moment of racial reckoning, few have made plans to change or even discuss their school mascots, despite mounting criticism from students and alumni.

Not recognizing the humanity of everyone, especially those whose skins were not white, is so ingrained.”
